it.unifi.rc.httpserver.m5951907.handler

Class MyHTTPHandler1_1

  • java.lang.Object
    • it.unifi.rc.httpserver.m5951907.handler.AbstractHTTPHandler
      • it.unifi.rc.httpserver.m5951907.handler.MyHTTPHandler1_0
        • it.unifi.rc.httpserver.m5951907.handler.MyHTTPHandler1_1
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    HTTPHandler, MyHTTPHandler

    public class MyHTTPHandler1_1
extends MyHTTPHandler1_0
    Implements an handler that serves HTTP/1.1 requests. N.B. not all methods specified by the 1.1 protocol has been implemented: TRACE and CONNECT returns a 501 Not Implemented response.
    Author:
    Simone Cipriani, 5951907

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      MyHTTPHandler1_1(java.io.File root)
      Basic constructor, initializes the handler to serve independently of the requesting host.
      MyHTTPHandler1_1(java.lang.String host, java.io.File root)
      Construct the handler to serve only a specific host.

      private java.lang.StringBuilder getStdHeaderFields()
      Since this handler handle HTTP/1.1 requests and I do not plan to implement persistent connections in server, each request generated by this class will include in its header fields the token "Connection: close".

      • getStdHeaderFields

        private java.lang.StringBuilder getStdHeaderFields()
        Since this handler handle HTTP/1.1 requests and I do not plan to implement persistent connections in server, each request generated by this class will include in its header fields the token "Connection: close".
        Returns:
        a StringBuilder with standard header parameters already set

      • handlingImplementation

        protected HTTPReply handlingImplementation(HTTPRequest req)
                                    throws MyHTTPProtocolException
        Description copied from class: AbstractHTTPHandler

        Returns:

      • implementDELETE

        private HTTPReply implementDELETE(java.lang.String path,
                                  java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> pars)
                           throws HTTPProtocolException
        Basic implementation of the DELETE method. It mimics an authentication system by checking a certain header parameter. Nothing really usable in the real world, but it serves to show the concept.
        Parameters:
        path - of resource to be deleted
        Returns:
        a HTTPReply
        Throws:
        HTTPProtocolException - if something does not work

      • implementPUT

        private HTTPReply implementPUT(java.lang.String path,
                               java.lang.String entityBody)
                        throws HTTPProtocolException
        Basic implementation of the PUT method.
        Parameters:
        path - in which the entity will be created
        entityBody - to be written in the entity
        Returns:
        a HTTPReply, as specified by the protocol
        Throws:
        HTTPProtocolException - if something goes nuts
